Sessions.Title: First General Session with John C Maxwell
Sessions.Description: John C Maxwell is a number 1 New York Times bestselling author, speaker, coach, and leader who has sold more than 33 million books in 50 languages. He has been called the No. 1 leader in business and the most influential leadership expert in the world. His organizations — the John Maxwell Company, the John Maxwell Team, EQUIP, and the John Maxwell Leadership Foundation — have translated his teachings into 70 languages and used them to train millions of leaders from every country in the world. A recipient of the Horatio Alger Award and the Mother Teresa Prize for Global Peace and Leadership from the Luminary Leadership Network, Dr. Maxwell influences Fortune 500 CEOs, the presidents of nations, and entrepreneurs worldwide.

Sessions.Title: Second General Session with Inky Johnson and A Moderated Discussion with Commissioner Mike Morath
Sessions.Description: Inky Johnson grew up living in his grandparents’ two-bedroom house with 13 other family members, sleeping on a pallet on the living room floor. Drugs and violence surrounded him in his hometown, and stability was non-existent. Johnson knew that if he was to survive, he had to get out. While playing football at the University of Tennessee, he suffered nerve damage in a career-ending injury that nearly killed him and left him with paralysis in his right arm. He used the experience to advocate for the disabled and write the autobiographical book Inky: An Amazing Story of Faith and Perseverance. Johnson is the host of the Serendipity with Inky Johnson podcast. Whether the topic is leadership, teamwork or perseverance, he inspires his audience.

Sessions.Title: Third General Session with George Couros
Sessions.Description: George Couros is a worldwide leader in the area of innovative teaching, learning, and leading, and has a focus on innovation as a human endeavor. His belief that meaningful change happens when you first connect to people’s hearts is modeled in his writing and speaking. In his 20-plus years in the field of education, he has worked at all levels of school, from K-12 as a teacher, technology facilitator, and school and district administrator, and is currently an adjunct instructor with the Graduate School of Education at the University of Pennsylvania. Couros is also the author of The Innovator’s Mindset: Empower Learning, Unleash Talent, and Lead a Culture of Creativity, Innovate Inside the Box, and his latest release, Because of a Teacher.

Sessions.Title: Region 13 ESC Breakfast
Texas Council of Professor & Educational Administation Meeting
Texas A&M - Commerce Alumni & Friends Reception
Region 8 & 12 ESC Legislative Luncheon
Texas Association of Latino Administrators and Superintendents Meet & Greet
Sessions.Location: Four Seasons Hotel - San Jacinto Ballroom

Sessions.Title: Special Education Self Assessment Process
Sessions.Description: Are you new to self assessments or looking to improve your process?  We will walk through our entire process from start to finish for state-mandated self-assessments. We will discuss and show examples of how to include the findings into your district and department improvement plans.

Sessions.Title: AP Computer Science Principles: A Pathway to Student Success
Sessions.Description: Computer science is the engine that powers the technology, productivity, and innovation that drive today's world. Computer science coursework is fundamental for students' success in the workforce of tomorrow. In this session, learn how a diverse population of students are succeeding in AP Computer Science Principles, and hear about opportunities to add or expand this course in any district.

Sessions.Title: CCMR Tracking: Data, Data, and More Data
Sessions.Description: College, Career, and Military Readiness (CCMR) indicators are found throughout the accountability system. How do schools ensure they are getting all the credit for indicators at the district level? In addition, districts can receive additional funds for certain indicators meeting criteria. During this session, explore all the CCMR indicators and understand how to track and code so your district can optimize its CCMR through accountability.

Sessions.Title: Successfully Supporting District Strategic Priorities: Drive Improvement Planning with Data
Sessions.Description: The Aldine ISD Department of Strategic Initiatives and Accountability will share their process for equipping district and school leaders with the tools needed to effectively use multiple data sources in the improvement planning process. This session will outline tools, training, and resources that can be used to support leaders in identifying growth areas and monitoring progress throughout the year.

Sessions.Title: Telling District Stories through Community-Based Accountability
Sessions.Description: Learn how three districts of various sizes and from different areas of the state are telling their stories through Community-Based Accountability Systems (CBAS). Participants will gain insight on how the CBAS process can and does provide a framework for not only being accountable to things that truly matter, but also assists in creating a strong, meaningful brand for school districts.

Sessions.Title: Data Literacy: from Analysis to Action
Sessions.Description: With so many data sources, districts can find themselves data rich but information poor. Data literacy gives districts the skills to read, understand, create, and communicate data as information that moves beyond analysis to action. Participants will learn a system for prioritizing data sets that go beyond high stakes to include multiple measures. Capacity-building processes and protocols to support understanding, engagement, and analysis for action will be shared with attendees.

Sessions.Title: Using Data to Lead Systemic Improvement: Transforming through Evidence-Based Reform
Sessions.Description: This session is designed to allow participants to reflect, set measurable goals, and explore the stages of transformation to yield intended growth results. Through discourse on shared experiences, participants will gain varied insight that support transformational leadership and transformational campus settings.

Sessions.Title: CCMR Planning and Documentation for Small Districts
Sessions.Description: Hear how a CCMR team improved district procedures and created organizational documents to create a team-run system to improve CCMR in a small district.

Sessions.Title: If You're a Chip Off the Old Block, Is Your Future Set in Stone?
Sessions.Description: Come join other superintendents in a learning and brainstorming session exploring ways we can build programmatic ideas to entice future teachers within our communities, such as with job skills training, community partnerships, etc., and at the same time share potential solutions to support our students, staff, and communities by taking a multi-generational approach. Participants will have access to ideas generated as we build a knowledge toolkit.

Sessions.Title: CCMR: How to Survive and Thrive!
Sessions.Description: Denton ISD has spent the past three years developing new processes and initiatives to increase the likelihood that students graduate with College, Career, and Military Readiness (CCMR). This presentation examines: the formation, evolution, and guiding principles of the committee; data tools and strategies used to achieve distict goals; related HB 3 goals and initiatives; improvement seen over the last three years; adaptations to changes in learning due to COVID; and goals for the future.

Sessions.Title: A Partnership to Fulfill a Future-Ready Learner Profile
Sessions.Description: Learn how Frisco ISD is developing district-wide systems and supports that create an instructional focus based on deeper learning concepts. Beginning with implementation in a comprehensive high school structure, the presenters will discuss the ways Frisco ISD is supporting the fulfillment of the Future-Ready Learner Profile at two of its newest high schools.

Sessions.Title: Creating Sustainable Post-Secondary Success Cultures for Students through Community and Partnership
Sessions.Description: With the unique variables and challenges of each district, seeking solutions to meet the diverse needs of all students requires creative problem-solving. In partnering with OnRamps, learn how three Texas school districts, each with distinct strengths and needs‚ sought to increase the number and diversity of high school students who engage in college credit-bearing courses. See how they continue to foster that culture today!

Sessions.Title: Rethinking Career Readiness for the Post-Career Era
Sessions.Description: How can districts prepare students for a life of fulfillment and prosperity as "gig work" becomes the norm and a shrinking few will experience a traditionally linear "career?" This session will explore how forward-thinking districts and universities are preparing students for the future of work, then challenge participants to collaboratively imagine the next chapter of post-secondary preparation for students across the state of Texas and beyond.

Sessions.Title: Summer Enrichment for Diverse Learners
Sessions.Description: Participants will experience an interactive presentation learning Willis ISD's process of planning and implementing their summer enrichment program. The session will cover Willis ISD's "why" for planning and implementing a summer enrichment program. Presenters will discuss the curriculum of the program, including areas of STEM, Literature, CTE, and Fine Arts. Participants will learn about how Willis ISD staff met the needs of all students.

Sessions.Title: Implementing Reading and Writing Across the Curriculum for ALL students
Sessions.Description: Participants will learn about instructional methods and strategies to ensure the inclusion of reading and writing for all students in both language arts classrooms and cross-curricular settings. Discover key ways to accelerate learning through reading engagement, while focusing on strategies and activities to engage all readers to think like scientists and write like historians. Highlight tools to enhance instructional planning across departments to bring forward authentic work in every discipline.

Sessions.Title: CCMR Accountability Requirements and the District Resources to Ensure Success
Sessions.Description: Hear broad and versatile points of view from six different ISDs in Regions 1,2,10,11, and 18. Each district has unique needs and solutions. This discussion will illuminate realistic programming that applies to each district. The panelists will share content areas that are top priorities in their districts, and discuss the challenges and successes they have experienced while implementing a systemic CCMR curriculum.

Sessions.Title: Creating Community Ownership: The Power of Scaled Conversations
Sessions.Description: When it comes to district-wide conversations, the need to belong and feel heard is greater than the need to be right. Yes, asking for input takes courage. But what's worse: hearing what everyone thinks or hearing only from a few claiming to represent everyone? Effective leaders leverage technology across socio-political, language, and connectivity barriers. Join district leaders as they share logistics, fears, and possibilities in scaling conversations on critical issues.

Sessions.Title: School Nightingales: Nursing Learning Community Back to Classrooms
Sessions.Description: A presentation led by Laredo ISD Student Services staff and Health Services Coordinator will detail how to plan, organize, deliver, and articulate health services to our local community in a time of crisis. Developing shared goals and objectives with city health authorities facilitated the collaborative efforts necessary to host joint vaccine clinics for school staff, students, and the community. Video and media advisories will be shared with the audience.

Sessions.Title: TSPRA: PR and the Superintendent
Sessions.Description: The art of great PR is an essential skill for every superintendent. As equally important is the relationship school leaders have with their public relations people. Learn how trust, vision, confidence, and rapport are essential ingredients to any district's success.

Sessions.Title: The Van Vleck Story: How a District Successfully Reinvented Itself through 1 Bond Cycle
Sessions.Description: In 2017, it had been 45 years since Van Vleck ISD in Matagorda County had been able to pass a bond program successfully. To the surprise of the entire community, on November 7, 2017, the $88.2 million bond passed. This session delves into the story of how the bond passed, but also what happened afterward to turn the entire program into an amazing success.

Sessions.Title: Increasing Student Achievement and Growing Educators through Innovative Learning Partnerships
Sessions.Description: Experience a panel discussion exploring community learning partnerships through purposeful conversations with school district, university, and informal education institution leaders. Community learning partnerships transform learning experiences for students by focusing on the development of the whole child through curiosity, creativity, and critical thinking to prepare students to be future-ready. The session explores relevant teacher professional development, student learning excursions that provide real world experiences, and meaningful community partnerships.

Sessions.Title: TSPRA: Breaking Down the Decline in Enrollment: Complex Issues with a Communications Focus
Sessions.Description: Modeled after a popular roundtable at the 2021 TSPRA Annual Conference, participants will learn about the varied and unique enrollment challenges facing public schools. The session will include an overview of trending enrollment data, specific district examples of enrollment obstacles, and communications strategies to begin addressing the issues, with opportunities for feedback and discussion. Declining enrollment is a shared issue across the state and district leaders can face it together.

Sessions.Title: Fleas, Bees, and Flooding, Oh My! Managing Crisis and Building Trust as a New Leader
Sessions.Description: From managing a massive flea outbreak, uncovering an 80-foot beehive at a campus, leading through a pandemic, and navigating various other crises big and small, trust and engagement between the superintendent and the community increased through strategic and authentic communication. Learn how a new superintendent and communications director worked together to lean into strengths and authenticity in order to engage the community and build trust in times of crisis.

Sessions.Title: Redefining the School Customer Experience
Sessions.Description: What do community engagement, student retention and teacher satisfaction have in common? For a district to be truly good at any of these, its leaders must embrace a commitment to listening. Learn how administrators at El Paso ISD have focused on improving community engagement and customer service by providing team members with the tools and the soft skills needed to build meaningful relationships with stakeholders

Sessions.Title: Engagement for Enrollment, Trust, and Culture
Sessions.Description: Edcouch-Elsa ISD uses routine family and staff engagement to hear from multilingual stakeholders, strategically plan, and strengthen culture. Learn about EEISD's systems and processes to engage and strategically plan with stakeholders, and hear about national family and staff trends to inform strategic plans for districts and schools. Using an Equitable Planning framework, participants will discuss and plan their next steps.

Sessions.Title: Industry and School Connections for CCMR School Models in a Small District
Sessions.Description: Join this session to learn how one district leveraged locally connected school staff to find industry partnerships. Additionally, reflection opportunities will occur for districts to review their own profiles to support increased industry connection for increased community engagement.

Sessions.Title: TSPRA: Take Communications to the Next Level with Social Media Strategies That Work
Sessions.Description: Have a strong social media presence? Are district social media posts engaging? Pay to boost posts? Social media is an essential component of a district's communication plan and a great way to build stakeholder trust, confidence, and loyalty. Evaluate district social media strategies and leave this session with ideas designed to create meaningful connections with stakeholders.

Sessions.Title: Addressing the Rural Teacher Shortage
Sessions.Description: The rural teacher shortage is real! Sunray ISD is implementing strategies and programs to not only address the shortage, but also provide opportunities for members of their community to develop into strong educators.

Sessions.Title: Coordinated Support of New Teachers Using a Teacher Development Framework Based on T-TESS
Sessions.Description: A collaborative representing small and large districts, INSPIRE Texas ACP, and the Innovation Center 4 Educator Preparation reorganized T-TESS to create a benchmarked tool for coaching first-year teachers. This panel will share the Teacher Development Framework with coaching questions and look-fors, the process for collaboration, outcomes from the pilot of the tool, and next steps based on lessons learned.

Sessions.Title: A New World of Bridging Recruitment and Retention
Sessions.Description: Are you facing challenges with recruitment and retention? Come learn how our district experienced increased success in finding and retaining teachers. Participants will experience the various recruitment and retention campaigns Gainesville ISD went through in order to share information about the district to draw interest from candidates. We will cover our staff on radar meetings, stay interviews, coffee chats, virtual job fairs, social media campaign, and onboarding teams.

Sessions.Title: Teacher Induction Programs: The Key to Retaining Highly Qualified Staff
Sessions.Description: Teacher recruitment and retention of highly qualified teachers is a need shared by every school district, whether large or small. This session will discuss and examine how to provide the needed professional development supports for all induction-year teachers, while also supporting the individualized needs that surface. By balancing professional learning with coaching, mentoring, and the occasional counseling, a school district can ensure that they retain highly qualified staff members.

Sessions.Title: Accommodating Disabilities in the Workplace
Sessions.Description: Administrators and supervisors need to know how to respond to employees who need an accommodation because of a disability, medical issue, or return-to-work limitations. Challenges include determining what qualifies as a disability, identifying reasonable accommodations, and ensuring the process is interactive. HR Services consultants will provide a commonsense approach to implementing a process that is efficient and compliant with the requirements of the Americans with Disabilities Act.

Sessions.Title: Teacher Recruitment and Retention: Two Sides of the Same Shrinking Coin
Sessions.Description: Participants will be glad they attended this interactive presentation in which they will see how they can adjust current recruiting practices to increase their talent pools while also retaining more staff by engaging staff in regular recognition, development, and decision-making opportunities. Join Brandon and Patricia and walk away ready to revamp human resources practices in your district!

Sessions.Title: Retired Educators as Mentors
Sessions.Description: Steal from the experts and the experience. Come hear how one district created a mentor program using retired educators to support and encourage the newbies to the teaching profession. The experiences and knowledge is comforting and helpful, while the lack of competition or evaluation from the retiree presents a safe and nurturing environment. The new teachers love this chance to learn from the experts, and the retirees love giving back.

Sessions.Title: Beyond Sports: Title IX in Extracurricular Activities
Sessions.Description: The Office for Civil Rights interprets Title IX to protect students from discrimination on the basis of sexual orientation and gender identity. In this session, three school lawyers will explore new cases, agency guidance, and state authority on sex discrimination in a variety of school activities, including fine arts, CTE, and athletics. They'll discuss best practices for tryouts, uniforms, and overnight trips, as well as appropriate responses to discrimination claims.

Sessions.Title: Qualifying an Uncertified Teacher
Sessions.Description: Many school districts are challenged with finding certified teachers for hard-to-fill positions and areas with limited certified applicants. Experienced TASB HR Consultants will help attendees learn the basics of certification and take a deep dive into creative solutions for qualifying an uncertified teacher. Nontraditional routes to certification, types of certificates and permits, and criteria for meeting certification requirements will be discussed.

Sessions.Title: Growing District Capacity: National Board Certification
Sessions.Description: Are you ready to grow your district's instructional capacity? Come join us and imagine the possibilities of bringing the National Board process to your school district! Attendees will see prospective models of National Board cohort guidelines, timelines, and resources as well as engage in ongoing networking and conversation for specific district needs. Join us and start your journey to a rewarding process for the teachers in your district!

Sessions.Title: Building Trust and Understanding in a Robust Educator Evaluation System
Sessions.Description: Campus principals and district leaders, side by side, will share the learning journey taken together in applying a robust educator evaluation system with student growth measures to teacher evaluation in their district. Learn how the leadership developed a learning community to build trust and understanding to improve the implementation efforts.  Principals share changes to practice by developing a common understanding of criteria along with the wins in improving teacher practice.

Sessions.Title: After ESSER Dollars Are Spent, What's Left?
Sessions.Description: School districts across the nation are planning to spend an unprecedented amount of stimulus funds. Districts should be asking themselves, "after these funds are spent, what's left?" The answer: Human Capital Increased Capacity. This session will cover how to increase educator capacity and effectiveness through individualized job-embedded coaching and other scalable strategies to give educators the support they need to accelerate learning and increase student achievement.

Sessions.Title: Retaining Teachers through Challenging Times
Sessions.Description: Retaining great teachers in the classroom is essential to student success. Growing student populations, shifting accountability policies, and new instructional contexts are impacting teacher retention. Through intentional systems of feedback and support, school leaders can keep their faculty engaged in the work of promoting positive student outcomes.  This session will use narratives from effective school leaders to provide context on navigating the issue of teacher support and retention.

Sessions.Title: Cultivating Teacher Talent for Rural Texas: A System Approach Linking Districts and Post Secondary Institutions
Sessions.Description: This session describes an emerging program aiming to cultivate teacher talent for rural schools. The context for regional teacher shortages reveals the value of applying a systems theory approach, and a partnership among four universities, nine community colleges, and 64 school districts in rural Texas creates an inter-organizational system to provide sorely needed, high-quality teachers for rural schools. Rural districts in West Texas will have opportunities to join this partnership.

Sessions.Title: SEL and Teacher Retention
Sessions.Description: Teacher turnover costs districts approximately $12,000 per teacher per year. This session will assist administrators in the importance of SEL and PBIS programs in lowering teacher turnover, increasing job satisfaction, and retaining teachers for longevity.
Sessions.Track Name(s): Student Support Services and Vulnerable Populations

Sessions.Title: The "Secret Sauce" of Dyslexia Intervention: How Can It Help Improve Outcomes for ALL Students?
Sessions.Description: Not every student struggles with reading for the same reason, so instruction and interventions must be individualized in order to maximize learning and narrow gaps caused by learning loss or other factors. Participants will engage in direct instruction from the presenter, small group discussion, and collaborative planning that will empower them to lead their teams in creating meaningful, data-based instructional plans to help individualize reading instruction for all students.
Sessions.Track Name(s): Student Support Services and Vulnerable Populations

Sessions.Title: Special Education 101: Discipline of Students with Disabilities
Sessions.Description: Discipline of students with disabilities can be complicated. Join Kelly Janes and Denise Carter as they break down the challenging rules surrounding disciplining students with disabilities, including recent legislative updates. They will draw from their experience as they offer practical strategies for addressing common issues and ensuring legal compliance. These include tracking FAPE - free days, monitoring behavior intervention plans, and dealing with manifestation determination review meetings.
Sessions.Track Name(s): Student Support Services and Vulnerable Populations

Sessions.Title: How to Best Serve Students in the Non-Traditional Educational Settings
Sessions.Description: This session will include a focus on our students who are in a special population within a non-traditional setting. We will discuss how the campus of Community Services School has the opportunity to serve and support students within Houston ISD who are unable to attend a traditional campus. We will discuss instructional practices, resources, and how students' needs are supported on our campus.
Sessions.Track Name(s): Student Support Services and Vulnerable Populations

Sessions.Title: Truancy ... County Court or District Support? The Plano ISD Attendance Review Board (PARB)
Sessions.Description: Learn from a Community-Building Activity Group discussion on existing truancy and intervention efforts used in school districts, learn the specifications (ex. documents, data, mediator info, etc.) of the PARB, and answer reflective questions to review lessons learned from PARB Action planning. Time will be allotted for participants to leverage information acquired from the session to develop a highly effective internal platform to achieve greater equity in decreasing truancy .
Sessions.Track Name(s): Student Support Services and Vulnerable Populations

Sessions.Title: An Evidence-Based Approach to Reducing Chronic Absenteeism and Improving Student Outcomes
Sessions.Description: Join EveryDay Labs for an interactive panel discussion around strategies proven to reduce chronic absenteeism district-wide. Derek Little, deputy chief of academics for Dallas ISD, will speak about Operation Comeback, an initiative that successfully re-engaged students after the pandemic by addressing barriers to attendance. Discuss the research behind effective practices, and hear from district leaders who've successfully used data and insights to inform their practices from implementation to evaluation.
Sessions.Track Name(s): Student Support Services and Vulnerable Populations

Sessions.Title: Improving Significant Disproportionality through SEL, Capacity Building, Restorative Practices, and Connecting Campus Leaders' Interests/Ownership
Sessions.Description: Districts are faced with reducing disproportionality for students removed from class, but a general path to this goal has not been established. Due to this, districts must be innovative in the process. In this session, dive deeper into significant disproportionality. Attendees will explore activities/actions that Bellville ISD took through SEL, capacity building, restorative practices (and more) to reduce disproportionality, and how connecting campus leaders' interests and ownership transformed the process.
Sessions.Track Name(s): Student Support Services and Vulnerable Populations

Sessions.Title: Using Data to Create a Sustainable, Equitable, and Adaptive Mental Health Model
Sessions.Description: Student mental health is essential to learning and interconnected with the health of families and schools. Georgetown ISD leaders will share their ongoing process to evaluate and refine their MTSS to identify, triage, and address student mental health needs and create sustainable, community-wide solutions. This interactive discussion will cover how GISD leveraged funding, prevention strategies, data, and an innovative partnership with Care Solace to ensure equitable allocation and access to resources.
Sessions.Track Name(s): Student Support Services and Vulnerable Populations

Sessions.Title: Top 10 Special Education Issues
Sessions.Description: Administrators play key roles in ensuring programs in their district meet the needs of the children and community. Review requirements, self analyze current standings, and create a plan of action to move a program to the next step. The session will provide a primer on major special programs for attendees as well as a framework and questions that can assist leaders in overseeing efficient, effective and compliant programs.
Sessions.Track Name(s): Student Support Services and Vulnerable Populations

Sessions.Title: Integrating SEL & Well-Being into the MTSS Conversation
Sessions.Description: Curious about rolling out SEL district-wide and building buyin? Eager to align behavior and academic support? Join us for a panel discussion with Panorama Education and their large district partners to learn how to make SEL the glue to your MTSS framework. Assess, support, and prioritize SEL to ensure all students are matched with what they need to succeed.
Sessions.Track Name(s): Student Support Services and Vulnerable Populations

Sessions.Title: All Systems Go!
Sessions.Description: 3-2-1 lift off! Early intervention is key to meeting desired outcomes in student achievement. Join us on the launchpad to identify early indicators specific to students' academic, social, and emotional needs; ways to employ early intervention processes to promote success; and how to align district systems for cohesiveness to ensure teacher support and systemic continuous improvement.
Sessions.Track Name(s): Student Support Services and Vulnerable Populations

Sessions.Title: Pandemic Pushout: Closing Equity Gaps Widened by Closures
Sessions.Description: The pandemic elicited a story of divides: learning and income divides that disproportionately affected black and brown students. Essential to closing these gaps is creating a culture of showing up; we won't have lasting change until we improve attendance. Join us as Ector County ISD leaders share how they implemented a MTSS model, leveraging culturally relevant messages and outreach, to connect with families, identify barriers to attendance, and create a welcoming school environment.
Sessions.Track Name(s): Student Support Services and Vulnerable Populations

Sessions.Title: From Crisis to Reunification: Creating a Detailed Reunification Plan Using Standard Response Protocol (SRP)
Sessions.Description: During this multimedia presentation, participants will follow the two-year journey to a completed Reunification Emergency Operations plan using Standard Response Protocol. Participants will learn about the steps taken to produce the plan and see the final product.

Sessions.Title: School Safety Communication and De-escalation of Conflict
Sessions.Description: Participants will be informed on a wide range of strategies for understanding communication and de-escalation as it pertains to the school environment. Topics covered in this session will include ego states, verbal and non-verbal communication techniques, communication for non-violent conflict resolution, and techniques for de-escalation of potentially volatile situations. The students will be exposed to proven practices in non-violent conflict resolution.

Sessions.Title: Providing the BESST Supports for Students of Trauma
Sessions.Description: Weatherford ISD's creation of the district-level BESST (Behavior, Emotional, Social, Support Team) provides campus supports for students who have experienced trauma resulting in academic and/or behavior struggles. Participants will learn the steps to early identification of students with trauma in order to provide appropriate interventions. The program development, the successes, as well as the adjustments that have been made will be shared during this session.

Sessions.Title: Strong, Proud, and Ready: Lifelines in a Time of Change and Challenge
Sessions.Description: Successful organizations thrive when departments work together, especially during challenging times. Participants will learn how LISD and the community joined hands to propel our students beyond the quarantines and isolation.  Experienced leaders will discuss instruction, HR, student services, and communications. A video, employee accommodations, parental engagement opportunities, samples of media releases, and social media postings are included. Learn how departments continued instruction while  keeping our children safe during the pandemic.

Sessions.Title: School Policing: Assess Before Arrest
Sessions.Description: The Round Rock ISD Police Department developed a model called the Four Pillars of School Policing that is a blueprint for transformative school policing. The model heavily promotes safety and security, student advocacy, civil and human rights through racial equity, and behavioral health. Through a lecture, presentation of case studies, and a facilitated discussion, participants will walk away with a deeper understanding of the importance of assessing before arresting.

Sessions.Title: Promote Staff and Students' Emotional Agility and Overall Wellness
Sessions.Description: More than ever before, staff and students need school leaders who are sensitive to the overall well-being of those they serve. Compassion fatigue, a leading cause of burnout amongst educators today, leaves educators unavailable to fully support the needs of their students, families, and themselves. By establishing systems of support, school leaders can mitigate the effects of toxic stress and create an environment where both staff and students can thrive.

Sessions.Title: Orange Frog: The Happiness Advantage
Sessions.Description: We've long believed that success drives happiness, but it turns out it's the other way around. When we are positive, our brains are more engaged, creative, motivated, energetic, resilient, and productive, both at work and in our personal lives. In this session, you'll learn how to reprogram your organization's collective brain to create an environment that promotes happiness and well-being, which are the precursors of sustainable performance.

Sessions.Title: School Safety Updates
Sessions.Description: The Texas School Safety Center housed at Texas State University is charged to oversee many state school safety mandates and trains and educates districts, charter schools, and junior colleges throughout the state. This training is geared specifically for district administrators who are looking for a bird's eye view of mandates and what is expected of their district.

Sessions.Title: Building a Culture of Safety & Support: Preventing the Next School Tragedy
Sessions.Description: Join Cypress-Fairbanks ISD leaders as they share how they are building the safest physical and emotional environment possible for students and staff. Several departments have collaborated on a holistic approach that encompasses both emergency preparedness and threat assessment in the district and in their community. The team will share their best practices and how they stay up to date with SB 11 and TEC 37.108 legislation.

Sessions.Title: Thriving in Hope, Well-being, and Engagement: A Year's Glance at Pandemic Recovery and Beyond
Sessions.Description: Welcome to Thriving! Hope, well-being, and engagement are huge priorities with extra importance in a pandemic recovery world. Come work through a framework that merges positive relationships, social-emotional learning, and curriculum into a calendar year. Resources, funds, and time are not limitations to this plan! Leaders have incredible influence, and this session is designed equip and empower leaders to help their school thrive!

Sessions.Title: Restorative Practices for Principals: Connecting with Your Staff
Sessions.Description: Participants will learn about Restorative Practices such as Restorative Circles and gain information on how to conduct them on their campus. They will also see video clips of reactions from different staff members from one organization that will help them see the value of such practices. Participants will leave with an arsenal of activities they can use on their home campuses.

Sessions.Title: Response to Pandemic: Lessons Learned
Sessions.Description: During the last few years, schools had to reset overnight to continue providing instruction and support services to students across their school systems. A panel of school superintendents and principals will share new approaches and strategies developed in real-time to support students, staff, and families. Findings from a study on transition to distance learning during the pandemic will also be presented.

Sessions.Title: CTO: COVID Reset--Strategies to Keep after the Pandemic
Sessions.Description: This session will address the challenges that districts faced as they abruptly pivoted to remote instruction, and how they can continue to focus and refine the initiatives put in place to improve as they seek to get "back to better." Participants will experience facilitated discussion with a moderator and district leaders from various school districts and will be able to take part in interactive activities based on the topics discussed.

Sessions.Title: The Pandemic Happened … Now What?
Sessions.Description: Participants will experience an open discussion with questions and answers regarding how COVID-19 created a catalyst for Edgewood ISD to leverage partnerships to provide a safe learning environment. The pandemic generated challenging circumstances for our community and EISD responded in a manner that will change the way we do business moving forward.

Sessions.Title: Texas Alliance of Boys and Girls Club Response to Learning Loss Call to Action
Sessions.Description: Now it is more important than ever for communities to partner with their local school districts to provide students the well-rounded support and robust set of services needed to close gaps in learning and ensure equity. Join The Texas Alliance of Boys and Girls Club Executive Team as they discuss their response to the critical need for double dose tutoring to address learning loss created by the pandemic.

Sessions.Title: How Strong District Leadership Can Lead a District to Success, Even During a Pandemic
Sessions.Description: Spring Break 2020 was unlike any other. The Arlington ISD sprang into action with students and staff as the focus. It didn't matter if it was feeding students or ensuring technology was available for a new way of learning, the district was up to the task. How did the Arlington ISD do it? By focusing on a shared vision of student success regardless of the situation.

Sessions.Title: Addressing the Mental Health Impacts of COVID-19 on Students and Educators
Sessions.Description: As schools move into recovery, the COVID-19 pandemic continues to magnify the mental health needs of students and educators. Students and educators are struggling with pandemic-related social isolation, anxiety, trauma, and grief. Attendees will learn how Texas districts are responding to these challenges and working to ensure schools have what they need to support student and educator emotional wellness in the months and years to come.

Sessions.Title: Leveraging Outcomes-Based Contracting to Maximize High-Dosage Tutoring
Sessions.Description: High-dosage virtual tutoring + outcomes-based contracting = results! In a project with Harvard University, Ector County ISD leveraged this formula to accelerate instruction and improve student performance. The ECISD superintendent and leadership team will present their process of implementation and best practices. They'll address topics like Outcomes-Based Contracts and RFPs, incentivized payment structures, tutoring program areas of focus, prioritization of students, delivery modes, schedules, and team assembly.

Sessions.Title: What's Going On with Our Stressed Out Teens?: The Neuroscience of Adolescence
Sessions.Description: Stress, anxiety, and depression are on the rise across every age group and demographic. The list of stressors is long, but none have been more far-reaching than the impact of COVID-19 on students, families, educators, and communities. This presentation will focus on the vulnerable adolescent student population and the need for the purposeful integration of SEL in every school and district.

Sessions.Title: 21st Century Sex Ed: How Districts Can Prepare to Implement Updated Sex Education Standards
Sessions.Description: Recent changes by the State Board of Education to curriculum standards that guide K-12 health education, including sexual health education, offer opportunities to help students delay sexual activity, increase protection against pregnancy and sexually transmitted infections, and be prepared for a lifetime of sexual health. Presenters will describe changes to the Health Education Texas Essential Knowledge and Skills (TEKS) and offer resources and tools to support curriculum adoption and implementation.

Sessions.Title: School Investigations: Be Ready
Sessions.Description: Today's school environment has created the need for thorough investigations with the increase of bullying, harassment, discrimination, grievances, and many other issues. Superintendents must be able to identify when and how to initiate investigations in order to collect information to make appropriate decisions based on fact finding, and many times to ultimately make recommendations to the board of trustees or avoid costly legal consequences.

Sessions.Title: UIL Updates
Sessions.Description: Presenters will share general information regarding the UIL and its rules, along with specific information concerning recent changes, trends, and UIL competition. Participants will have the opportunity to ask questions and provide input to the UIL.

Sessions.Title: Employment Law Update 2021: A Review of New Cases under State and Federal Law
Sessions.Description: This session is designed to update participants on new case law related to employment issues and to develop strategies to reduce or mitigate employment issues in the future.

Sessions.Title: Transgendered Students' Rights under the Biden Administration: The Pendulum Swings Back
Sessions.Description: Do schools now have to let transgender students use bathrooms and dressing rooms of their identified gender? The U.S. Department of Education recently issued a new interpretation of the Department's enforcement authority over discrimination based on sexual orientation and gender identity under Title IX. This session will examine and discuss areas of potential liability for school districts in addressing the needs of transgender students.

Sessions.Title: How to Have and Keep a Seat at the Legislative Table
Sessions.Description: this session will include an in-depth discussion on how superintendents and district leaders can earn access to being involved in the true legislative decision-making process. Critical decisions are made at the end of each legislative session around the "table" behind closed doors. Engage in a discussion with those leaders who are invited to sit at the table.

Sessions.Title: Surviving OCR Investigations: A Practical Guide
Sessions.Description: What can you expect when you receive notice from the Office for Civil Rights that a parent has filed a complaint of discrimination against your district? What documents do you need to prepare?  What witnesses will be interviewed?  Do you want to try to resolve this matter through an informal resolution process?  This presentation will walk you through the process with practical pointers to make the situation more manageable.

Sessions.Title: Uncivil Discourse: Managing Disruptive Comments and Complaints
Sessions.Description: School districts are facing questions, concerns, and even protests about current social and political issues from mask requirements to curriculum and beyond. Where’s the line between parent involvement and disruptive behavior? Join the current and immediate past chairs of the Texas Council of School Attorneys, in-house counsel for a growing district, and TASB's director of Legal Services for their best advice on how to navigate these heated situations.

Sessions.Title: Do Master Scheduling and Staffing Practices Support HB 4545 Accelerated Learning Requirements?
Sessions.Description: House Bill 4545 requires accelerated instruction practices for all students in the 2021-2022 school year. According to TEA, "this requirement will set up a significant need to rethink master schedules and staffing patterns." Come deconstruct this new legislation and leave with a plan for building a strategic master schedule and data-driven staffing plan that will maximize district resources and set supplemental instruction programs up for success.

Sessions.Title: The Superintendent's Contract: What Should and Should Not Be Included
Sessions.Description: The superintendent's position as chief executive officer of the district and their direct working relationship with the Board of Trustees render the superintendent's position unlike any other in the public education arena. Accordingly, the superintendent's employment contract must be specifically tailored to reflect and acknowledge the unique nature of the position. The  contract should provide a strong backbone of support for the superintendent/Board of Trustees relationship.

Sessions.Title: Cheerleaders, Social Media, and Extracurricular Codes of Conduct
Sessions.Description: For generations, courts viewed participation in extracurricular activities as a privilege, not a right, allowing for higher standards of behavior both in and outside school. Technology and social media brought new challenges; courts responded. This session will address what is and is not allowable under the Supreme Court's 2021 decision in B.L. v. Mahanoy when disciplining students for online, off-campus speech and social media contracts in extracurricular codes of conduct.

Sessions.Title: Selecting the Right People for the Right Seats on the Bus?
Sessions.Description: The session includes an opportunity to review current administrative selection processes and development of future administrators for their schools. Presenters will provide an overview of Garland ISD administrative Assessment Centers. The session will include discussions of best practices used by participants and provide an overview of the importance of the use of best practices and processes used to develop and select district administrators.

Sessions.Title: Grow Your Own Authentic Instructional Leadership Principal Pipeline
Sessions.Description: The session will provide an overview of authentic leadership experiences for aspiring principals in the district's Grow Your Own Leadership pipeline. Districts will learn how Grand Prairie ISD and Texas Tech University worked together to develop and build a strong leadership pipeline that supports the growth of teachers and students.

Sessions.Title: The Power of Principal Coaching Models
Sessions.Description: Principals have the second-most impact on student achievement, behind only teachers. If that is true, how districts support, coach, and challenge principals is critical. Join learners from Belton and Leander ISD in an interactive conversation to explore research, best practices, and strategies to support principals as instructional leaders.

Sessions.Title: Lifting Leadership: Caring, Coaching and Courageously Leading Teachers and Principals to Be Great For Kids
Sessions.Description: The greatest asset of any organization is its people, and this session provides every district leader "a way" to identify the abilities of each employee, and determine how to use the lifting formula to drive their individual growth. This system of developmental supervision will work for superintendents who want to lift their principals, and for principals who want to lift their teachers. When we lift, we grow greatness!

Sessions.Title: Innovative Human Capital Designs
Sessions.Description: The most important factor influencing student success is the teacher. Learn about different strategic staffing and compensation methodologies including Opportunity Culture, Teacher Incentive Allotment, and National Board Certification. Additional content will include the creation of talent pipelines and the design of personalized professional learning plans for each employee. Join this session to learn of those game-changing strategies that most effectively create and grow talent.

Sessions.Title: Unspoken Expectations Cannot Be Met
Sessions.Description: Since unspoken expectations cannot be met and professional peril resides in ambiguity, focused leadership is critical. Join a aanel of experienced administrators and recently retired superintendents as they reflect on their weariness of playing "whack-a-mole." The panel will discuss their experiences on how a superintendent attains focused leadership to drive continuous improvement.

Sessions.Title: K-12 Leadership Matters!
Sessions.Description: Hear from an award-winning superintendent and central office team as they discuss how they are moving the needle in their district transformation by providing personalized leadership support to new principals. This team has implemented professional development programs that best facilitate student learning and engagement while “building a bench” of school leaders ready to meet the complex challenges of K-12 leadership of the 21st century.

Sessions.Title: A "Learn by Doing" Approach to Leadership Development
Sessions.Description: School leaders can play an instrumental role in improving instruction and raising student achievement. In this session, learn why one district is moving to a "learn by doing" approach to leadership development via micro-credentials. In addition to learning about their leadership development program for principals and assistant principals, gain insight into what micro-credentials are, how they work, and why they are gaining momentum across the state.

Sessions.Title: Principal Retention: A Look at Best Practices
Sessions.Description: Participants will be presented with information they can use to help them create next steps for their organization in an effort to increase retention of quality principals. By applying the "Theory of Action" model, participants can decide what best practices can be used in their organization to help them grow quality principals, but more important, retain such valued employees.

Sessions.Title: Creating a Campus Game Plan through a Systems Thinking Approach
Sessions.Description: Wondering how to create and maintain instructional and operational systems to maximize campus leadership and student capacity? Game on! This session will provide an overview of the Seguin High School Campus Game Plan that can be adaptable for any K-12 setting. Come engage in dialogue with campus and district leadership, get a copy of the campus playbook, start to draft a campus game plan, and plan big.

Sessions.Title: Texas ASCD: Alignment of the System for Sustained Systemic Improvement
Sessions.Description: Connect, lead, and influence is the mantra for the Curriculum Leadership Academy (CLA) that concentrates on enhancing curriculum leaders' knowledge and skills. Preparing principals to lead transformative work that aligns to and supports delivery of the curriculum is critical to any sustained improvement by a district. Texas ASCD has two yearlong academies, facilitated by practitioners, that intentionally prepare curriculum leaders and principals to work interdependently to continuously improve student learning.

Sessions.Title: Chicken in the Locker: How to Coach Principals to Deal with the Expected and Unexpected
Sessions.Description: Participants will be challenged to evaluate their systems for coaching principals against seven essential questions for those coaching systems. Learn about essential topics such as principal coaching, decision-making, and principal evaluations. In the process, navigate several scenarios that no professional development ever trains principals to deal with.

Sessions.Title: How Healthy is Your Principal Pipeline?
Sessions.Description: Great principals are hard to replace. But with advance planning and smart use of data, districts can ensure there is someone ready to step into the role each time a position opens up. Learn to use data you already have to gauge the health of your principal pipeline, and to initiate a vacancy planning cycle that will ensure you are not caught off guard by retirements and departures.

Sessions.Title: Central Admin Leaders Supporting and Influencing Campus Transformation
Sessions.Description: The Executive Leadership Institute (ELI) is facilitated by N2 Learning in partnership with TASA to build the capacity of district executive leaders for system-wide improvements in teaching and learning. A panel of ELI participants will share how the strategic approaches and action developed in ELI support district and campus transformational efforts. The power of collegiality with the ELI network and an executive coach are highlighted as well.

Sessions.Title: Lead Like Dolly!
Sessions.Description: What can educators possibly learn from Dolly Parton? Like many public figures, she is so much more than what is seen. Dolly leaves nuggets of leadership in all that she does. Let's take a tour through Dolly's songs and Dollyisms for inspiration in leading and loving ourselves and those we lead. Let's take stock of ourselves as leaders, celebrate one another, have some fun, and love and lead like Dolly!

Sessions.Title: "It Ain't in the Book": What You Need to know About the Superintendency
Sessions.Description: Come learn from two national, regional, and state award-winning superintendents as they share leadership strategies and practices to promote successful transformation while thriving within the superintendency. We will discuss topics for those new to the superintendency that "ain't in the book!"

Sessions.Title: Supporting Campus Leaders through Effective Capacity-Building Systems
Sessions.Description: Join us as we share motivating best practices that are resulting in positive campus leadership development and a culture of focus on student benefit district-wide. How do you help campus leaders understand what their areas of focus should be? How do you build capacity throughout the district to create systems and processes that support student benefit? We'll share our story of a journey of learning that is continually moving forward!

Sessions.Title: Inside the Principal's Office: How to Guide and Lead Education's Toughest Job
Sessions.Description: Inside the Principal's Office is designed for those who supervise/mentor principals. We will share five different hats a principal wears: Instructional Leadership, Servant Leadership, Personal Growth, Communication, and Reflection/Celebration, and ways to improve in each. It can serve as a foundational guide that creates a framework for coaching conversations and/or further study. The purpose is to develop well-rounded campus leaders. If you work with principals, this is for you!

Sessions.Title: Leading through Change: Where Are You From? Tell Me Your Story!
Sessions.Description: There are more than 1,200 superintendents in Texas. Six of them — an anomalous group that graduated from Hebbronville High School from the 1970s through the 1990s — will share their story. Hebbronville is a small rural community located in deep South Texas. The panel will provide historical connections amongst the six superintendents and share a variety of ways that they have lead through change in their current and previous districts.

Sessions.Title: Next-Level Governance for Enhanced Student Performance
Sessions.Description: The XG (eXceptional Governance) Project is committed to helping trustees learn together what good governance looks like. We know good governance is focused, aligned, stretching, and tracking. Exceptional governance requires a highly effective board-superintendent partnership, an emphasis on a healthy culture among the team, and ongoing commitment to improvement. In this session, we dive into national research and best practices in governance, the value of board self-assessments, and opportunities to build a customized learning experience, including both your board and administrative teams. Leave with practical tips you can discuss and apply with your governance team.

Sessions.Title: CTO: Leadership Development for Ed Tech Leaders
Sessions.Description: The session will help superintendents, trustees, and cabinets influence the future of education technology leadership. Participants will experience a facilitated conversation focused on strategic initiatives designed by Texas Education Technology Leaders, followed by collaboration exploring an in-depth discussion about what districts need from their ed tech leaders. Learn how your district's ed tech leadership can be actively involved in advocacy, cohort groups, hot topic technology discussions and leadership development.

Sessions.Title: Getting Aligned: Leadership Development, Selection and Support
Sessions.Description: Presenters will share — through a mix of presentation, question and answer, and discussion format — the power of aligning processes in development, selection, and support for new district and campus leadership. Participants will explore equitably sound practices that include focus on value-based criteria, calibration, and norming, as well as explore multi-layered support for new leaders aligned to those values.

Sessions.Title: Developing Effective Campus Leadership Teams
Sessions.Description: Developing potential in others is a key practice for great leaders. Learn how Elgin ISD empowers school leaders with a path to shared leadership that, at once, builds positive school culture and supports effective implementation of evidence-based practices. School leaders will share their stories and strategies for building strong leadership teams and guide participants through collaboration with peers.

Sessions.Title: Creating Lifelines: Building and Investing in a Core Social Circle
Sessions.Description: As a leader, everyone needs an informal professional leadership community that creates a safe place to share, laugh, and solve our dilemmas, and it starts by identifying colleagues who will walk the same journey. These monthly informal gatherings allow for social-emotional support in a manner that is supportive, respectful, and full of laughter.

Sessions.Title: Mentorship Program Success in Developing Latino and Non-Latino Leaders
Sessions.Description: This session will focus on: describing the framework for the success of the TALAS Mentorship Program; sharing the current programs for Cohorts 7 and 8; and recruiting potential protegees for 2022.

Sessions.Title: The Superintendent Contract: Putting the Right Pieces Together to Meet Your Goals
Sessions.Description: A superintendent contract negotiation can be stressful, especially considering the impact it has on an individual's financial health, legal protection, and communication with the board. Understanding key provisions and techniques to make the contract uniquely fit a school leader's needs is critical, and this session will discuss strategies and approaches to help superintendents achieve their personal goals.

Sessions.Title: Leadership: Rocket Science or People Science?
Sessions.Description: Our session will appeal to leaders wanting to regain their passion to do what they are called to do as leaders by revisiting culture building and leadership development. Stop complicating the process; it's not rocket science!

Sessions.Title: 10 Things I Wish I Knew Before I Took This Job
Sessions.Description: Attendees will have an opportunity to take content and relate it back to their own district. The presenter has been a superintendent, principal, and now a large school athletic director. His experiences over 20 years provide lighthearted but strong lessons in leadership, creating a vision for a district, and lessons on navigating the potholes of the education system. Attendees will be engaged in this interactive learning opportunity.

Sessions.Title: Stronger Together: How Strengths-Based Teams Find Purpose, Power, and Potential
Sessions.Description: In the 2020-21 school year, three school districts brought a strengths-based approach to their leadership team in order to lead with purpose, power, and potential, creating the springboard for transformation. In this inspiring, informative, and entertaining session, three district leaders will share how the Clifton Strengths Assessment has positively impacted their leadership teams, finding the way forward to achieve strong outcomes for EVERY student.

Sessions.Title: Aspire: Striving and Thriving in the Next Level of Leadership
Sessions.Description: Each journey through campus and district leadership is unique. The process can be grueling and confusing, yet critical in education. From assistant principal to superintendent, attendees will hear from early career campus and district leaders as they reflect on lessons learned when interviewing, onboarding, and progressing in their new roles. Leaders aspiring for the next level will leave with ideas to prepare for the next step in their own journey.

Sessions.Title: The Tremendous Power of Positive Leadership
Sessions.Description: "Being positive won't guarantee you'll succeed, but being negative will guarantee you won't" - Jon Gordon. Whether wired like Tigger or Eeyore, regardless of where one leads or serves, the power of positive leadership is tremendous! Come talk about the power of positive leadership in school districts and share tips and resources to support unleashing the power in your own sphere of influence.

Sessions.Title: Rethinking Central Staff Performance and Leadership Development
Sessions.Description: This session will provide an overview of Dallas ISD's pilot evaluation instrument components and training protocol, internal and external leadership development portfolio, and team goals and projects. Presenters will discuss the Dallas ISD/University of Texas at Dallas Central Staff Leadership Development Program, including cohort levels, identification/selection processes, and alignment with district evaluation tools.

Sessions.Title: CTO: Tapping into the Potential of the Technology Leader
Sessions.Description: District technology leaders were called from the server room to the conference room during COVID to develop solutions for remote work and learning.  Superintendents, alongside their CTOs, were empowered to embrace new systems and technologies to increase efficiencies in cross-functional environments. This session will provide examples of work accomplished with these teams, and how they overcame challenges and implemented solutions. Learn how to tap into the potential of your technology leader!

Sessions.Title: Amplify Impact: Coaching Collaborative Teams from Central Office to the Classroom
Sessions.Description: Participants will experience an interactive visual presentation that will examine the why, what, and how of a Strategy Implementation Guide (SIG). The presentation will cover the journey of Willis ISD and how they used the SIG to develop collaborative teams and the role central office plays in its creation. Participants will be provided with tools to coach collaborative teams in the PLC process for clarity, support, and feedback.

Sessions.Title: 6 Step Process: Implementing Systems for High Performing Schools
Sessions.Description: Participants will learn six key steps that detail how Rockwall ISD created a system for curriculum development, writing common assessments, identifying the benefits of essential standards in curriculum, and coaching instructional leaders on best practices. Participants will walk away with access to our toolkit of resources that helped earn an 'A' rating in 2018 and 2019 and helped RISD stay the course during the COVID-19 pandemic.

Sessions.Title: No More Class Rank–One District's Path to Redefining Success
Sessions.Description: Participants will experience the path through the development of a strategic plan that drove out an action plan to eliminate class rank at a high performing high school. The steps taken to create the"why" behind the change for staff and the community will be reviewed, along with the data on increasing students' selection of individual pathways of interest and college acceptance.

Sessions.Title: Building a Systematic Approach to Saving Every Teacher and Leader
Sessions.Description: Student growth doesn't occur without educator growth, and educator growth does not occur without a school's intentional plan for their growth. In this powerful session, John Wink will share his new and improved Excellence Support System from his book, "A Leader's Guide to Excellence in Every Classroom," and give participants tools to immediately begin the process for building their own Excellence Support System.

Sessions.Title: Promoting Science of Reading and HB 4545 with Powerful Digital Tools
Sessions.Description: Recent research proves the effectiveness of the Knowledge Acquisition and Transformation (KAT) approach to strong reading comprehension in grades K through 8. In this session, we will present the evidence-based teaching practices, professional development and implementation fidelity approaches, and digital tools for students, teachers, and families. The digital tools include integration with textbooks. We successfully used these tools during the pandemic to make significant gains for children in multiple schools.

Sessions.Title: Friona ISD Lessons Learned with TIL
Sessions.Description: Friona ISD is in year three of TIL and have currently implemented three of the four levers: Observation Feedback, Lesson Alignment and Formative Assessments, and DDI. Join this session to discuss lessons learned through the process and growth seen in staff. Hear firsthand from the superintendent on the impact the process has had on his own learning as well as from other admin team members.

Sessions.Title: Using PBL to Engage Students and Accelerate Learning
Sessions.Description: So many students have left during COVID. After this session, participants will have practical instructional solutions that will enable them to create a learning environment that attracts students back in, ignites their engagement and gives them agency and choice. Accelerate student learning and high school credit completion for students who are labeled "alternative" by creating rigorous, high interest learning opportunities.

Sessions.Title: Refining Campus Leaders' Roles and Responsibilities to Support Instructional Leadership in Alignment to the ESF
Sessions.Description: We know the impact that clear expectations can have on student achievement, but how can we ensure that there is clarity for campus leadership teams as well? In this session, participants will review exemplar artifacts related the Effective Schools Framework, identify the success criteria evident in each artifact, and develop an action plan for refining current campus leaders' roles and responsibilities to ensure clarity and a focus on instructional leadership.

Sessions.Title: Planning for Instructional Impact, Before the Label
Sessions.Description: The basic design of the Effective Schools Framework, Texas Instructional Leadership Framework, and other research-based practices will be showcased to highlight the potential impact on instructional efficacy of such practices prior to a necessity due to state mandate. Time to discuss sustainable practices, such as goal setting and culture-building strategies, currently being used within participants' school districts to ensure instructional efficacy will be provided within the session as well.

Sessions.Title: Leveraging Instructional Coaching: Utilizing Content Specialist to Increase Teacher Effectiveness
Sessions.Description: Looking to optimize the role of instructional coaches or begin the process of hiring instructional coaches to help instructional leaders? Come discuss the role of content-specific instructional coaches from small and large district perspectives. Examine the challenges, leveraging coaches, and discuss steps to adopt the models discussed. Improve the efficacy of teachers by streamlining the work of instructional coaches.

Sessions.Title: Stop Adding One More Thing and Start Blending to Create Understanding
Sessions.Description: This session will support instructional leaders in blending their district-level initiatives with state or federal mandates.  The presentation will showcase the action research project of blending a school district's balanced literacy practices with House Bill 3 Reading Academy understanding. Presenters will discuss the research practice, its importance, the idea behind conceptual blending, the knowledge created through professional learning, and the increase of leadership efficacy.

Sessions.Title: Leadership Transparency on Student Learning Loss from Across Texas
Sessions.Description: Hear from three superintendents who pride themselves on being instructional leaders in their school districts. The presenters will provide samples of district instructional plans and speak to how they used resources to leverage every possible support to the students and staff to address learning loss exacerbated by the numerous disruptions to the school year, virtual learning, and high absentee patterns.

Sessions.Title: Connecting Across Districts: Collaboration at its Best
Sessions.Description: Participants will learn about the North Texas TIA Consortium and how it came to be formed. They will also have opportunity to discuss the various components of the Teacher Incentive Allotment. Several strategies will be used for participants to share what they are doing to implement the TIA and how each district has addressed the student growth measure. Questions and lingering issues will be addressed at the end.

Sessions.Title: Talking about Hard Things: Harnessing the Flow to Let Information Go
Sessions.Description: COVID, Critical Race Theory, and just navigating change in general, have required new rules for engaging our communities. In this session we'll learn from the experiences of two school communication professionals as they supported their superintendents through periods of communicating about difficult issues. We'll identify strategies for communicating with clarity and transparency, drawn from these lived experiences and the content from Anthony Kim's book, "The New School Rules."

Sessions.Title: Creating a Systematic Communication Plan That Gets Positive Results
Sessions.Description: The single biggest problem in communication is the illusion that it has taken place. Participants will walk away from this session with a clear understanding of what it takes to tell their story clearly, effectively, and in a timely manner. Buna ISD will describe how they created a Superintendent Student Advisory (SAC) Committee, Teacher Advisory Committee (TAC), and a Parent/Stakeholder Town Hall formum in order to enhance district culture and operations.

Sessions.Title: TSPRA: Opportunity Central: Transforming and Expanding the PK-12 Educational Model to the Community
Sessions.Description: Forney ISD shares how the concept of The OC, Opportunity Central, will change the way administrators think about public education. The idea that there is a retail, commercial, business, recreation, event center, higher education space where students can learn in an entrepreneurial track from business leaders will transform education.

Sessions.Title: TSPRA: 4 BONDS! 5 YEARS!
Sessions.Description: In the past six years, Cleveland ISD has proposed five bonds. Learn how this fast growth school district has found the best strategies for passing bonds and keeping their community informed.

Sessions.Title: $290 Million in Bonds Passed: Successes and Lessons Learned
Sessions.Description: Whether a district is booming with growth, or facilities are nearing end of life, trust and collaboration within the community is the only way to meet the needs of all students. Once the groundwork is in place, set projects up for success through thoughtful steering committee work, and learn how strategic communications, stakeholder empowerment, and district branding can lead to success at the polls.

Sessions.Title: Creating, Leading, Implementing and Sustaining Digital Innovation: Three Superintendent Perspectives
Sessions.Description: Superintendents are responsible for ensuring that their districts embrace transformative digital learning. Join this highly interactive conversation as three leading superintendents share the history, rationale, and strategies they use to successfully lead digital innovation for teaching and learning for all students, as well as managing school district operations effectively and efficiently. Walk away with strategies, tools, and resources for leading technology innovation in any district.

Sessions.Title: Computational Thinking + Content = Engagement: Leveraging Computer Science to Build Core Content Skills
Sessions.Description: Participants will take a look at Humble ISD's Coding+Beyond initiative developed to support K-12 students and teachers in a systemwide approach for engagement and success in core content through the use of computational thinking. Participants will explore how computer science principles can be incorporated into every subject as a way to increase student engagement and achievement through hands-on activities developed by teachers.

Sessions.Title: Purpose Driven Learning: The Future of Education
Sessions.Description: Students are empowered daily to make critical decisions about their learning experiences, how they will create and apply knowledge. Students learn actively using different pathways and programs to ensure equity for all students are embedded in the culture, design, and pedagogy of schools and education systems. Come learn how Mesquite ISD and Wichita Falls ISD are doing this through Purpose Driven Learning.

Sessions.Title: CTO: Cybersecurity Best Practices and Education
Sessions.Description: Participants will hear from a panel of two school districts - one large and one medium - working toward the Trusted Learning seal. Districts will share how they have implemented policies, procedures, practices, and creative cybersecurity educational plans to secure employee/student data and district technology resources that will minimize instructional and monetary losses. Participants will also be given opportunities to voice their district concerns and solutions.

Sessions.Title: Leveraging the COVID Disruption to Accelerate the Digital Transformation of K-12
Sessions.Description: Guiding Texas schools' transformation, today, is a set of powerful, prescient strategies identified in the 2008 report: "Creating a New Vision for Public Education in Texas." Article 1 in the report paints a vision of the transformative role that digital technologies can and will play. We will discuss concrete examples such as the digital transformation journey of K-5 schools in Michigan that were using resources now provided by University of North Texas' TCET.

Sessions.Title: Transforming Classrooms with Blended and Personalized Learning
Sessions.Description: To implement Blended Learning, what actions does your district need to take to move from vision to reality? Two Texas district leaders share strategies for planning, funding, working with their board, equipment and software selection, supporting their teachers, and educator professional development, with the end goal of optimal student learning in the digital age. Learn how educators moved from teacher-centered to learner-centered classrooms, where students are accountable for their learning.

Sessions.Title: Identifying and Collecting Key Performance Indicators for a K-12 Technology Program
Sessions.Description: Dr. Diane Frost, superintendent of Corsicana ISD, and Dr. Andy Berning, president of the Renaissance Institute, will provide an overview of their experience developing key performance indicators for CISD's technology program. They will discuss how modern learning analytics tools can be used to provide accountability and insight into not only the technology program, but district initiatives as well.

Sessions.Title: Pathways to Student Success: Northside ISD Credit Retrieval and Credit Protection Innovative Model
Sessions.Description: NISD will walk you through the "why" they have grown an innovative student support system to increase graduation rates through Credit Retrieval/Protection. Credit Protection has allowed students more time to build mastery and experience smaller successes along the way. Their oversight, support, and management of this district-wide blended and online programming for secondary students has transformed around the focus to provide students high-quality pathways to success — a key to equity.

Sessions.Title: Development Trials and Tribulations of Applying for the TIA in a Small to Mid-sized District
Sessions.Description: Applying for the Teacher Incentive Allotment (TIA) in a small to mid-sized district is a large task. Implementing a local designation plan can seem almost impossible with limited personnel. This session will walk participants through the rationale as well as methods for tracking student growth data and teacher performance data.

Sessions.Title: Accelerating Student Learning through Distance Learning Professional Development
Sessions.Description: OnRamps harnessed 10+ years of experience designing and delivering distance courses to launch the Distance Learning Catalog in 2020. The catalog provides fifth-grade educators and up with tools to strengthen, innovate, and adapt teaching practices in any classroom environment. Fort Worth ISD's Young Men's Leadership Academy leveraged the catalog as a forward-thinking solution for teachers and students to accelerate learning. Hear how and learn about catalog offerings available to districts across the state.

Sessions.Title: The BLUEprint for Success
Sessions.Description: Through presentation and discussion, participants will learn the steps to aggressively monitor instruction, make connections between each step and learn how to provide feedback to teachers to guide them toward teacher success and higher student achievement.
