Sessions.Title: Instructional Band Aids Don't Work: Planning Long-term Amid Short-term Pressures
Sessions.Description: Participants will learn about the instructional visioning and strategic planning process. Participants will practice elements of instructional visioning and examine the materials review process to ensure alignment with the vision. The goal is for participants to draw conclusions about and apply the instructional visioning process in their districts. By reviewing artifacts of student learning and mastery data, the connection between student outcomes and the instructional vision will become clear.

Sessions.Title: Designing Schools ... With Kids and Safety in Mind!
Sessions.Description: A panel of experts in their respective fields share how they combined forces and used data, best practices, and past experiences to create a learning environment that is safer than most traditional educational facilities used to educate kids. Learn what the overall impact was to the project's budget, and see building design features that were intentionally implemented as a result of lessons learned from past active shooter events.

Sessions.Title: Bridging Curriculum and Community–The Welch Outdoor Learning Center
Sessions.Description: Outdoor education has long introduced students to the sciences at an early age in a hands-on learning format. While the Welch Outdoor Learning Center in Katy ISD offers opportunities to explore the wonder of the outdoors during the school year, it also provides a venue for summer camps and community events. Through case study, hear how districts can meet and exceed the normal expectations for outdoor learning.

Sessions.Title: A Sinton Success Story: Passing a Bond in Today's Ever-Changing World
Sessions.Description: This session will share the Sinton ISD story, including the timeline, processes, materials and marketing used from inception until bond passage; and how all the above changed due to unforeseen circumstances. The session will include in-depth discussions on the financial impacts, community involvement, facility planning, marketing, and bond oversight.

Sessions.Title: Meeting the Needs of Early Childhood and Early Head Start Programs within Existing Space
Sessions.Description: Early childhood programs support two of Crowley ISD's district goals: "Thriving Students" and "Engaged Community." They serve a critical need of future students and working families and set the tone for reimagining existing classroom spaces that provide an ideal environment for early learners. With transformative design of a typical classroom, Crowley ISD has successfully delivered pre-kindergarten, Montessori, and Early Head Start programs at several existing campuses.

Sessions.Title: Next In Class Solar-Powered Schools
Sessions.Description: Many Fortune 100 school districts in Texas have made the prudent decision to invest in photovoltaic systems and these school sites are paying huge dividends! This session will give participants the keys to implement their own solar solutions with options for ground, roof, and/or canopy-mounted panels. Information on cost, ROI, and budget control will be included in the presentation.

Sessions.Title: School Gardens … Build. Grow. Learn.
Sessions.Description: What can a garden teach a child? Get first-hand information on how campus gardens can successfully contribute to students' academic success. Longview ISD has been successfully incorporating the growth of fruits and vegetables into everyday curriculum while opening the doors for community partnerships. How Longview ISD turned a campus garden into a district-wide initiative that benefited their Child Nutrition department with farm- to-table options for breakfast and lunch.

Sessions.Title: If a Bond is Out of the Question
Sessions.Description: Through a detailed presentation, participants will gain knowledge of maintenance tax notes and warranty deeds, and how they can be used for facility needs. The session will give detailed steps in securing and using these alternate funds to renovate and create new learning environments for school districts. If a community is not ready for a bond election, these funds are a great way to move the district forward.

Sessions.Title: Passing a Half-Billion Dollar Bond during a Pandemic: Leveraging Trust, Technology, and Social Media
Sessions.Description: District leaders will share lessons learned from a successful bond campaign during a pandemic from initial conversations to the long-range planning committee proces and the bond campaign. District leaders will provide handouts on timelines, tools, and resources to have a successful bond election.

Sessions.Title: Financial Inclusivity and Wellbeing--Serving Those Who Inspire!
Sessions.Description: Teaching and supporting educators is stressful enough––yet, most carry the added stress of not being able to pay bills, cover emergency expenses, or retire comfortably. Many ultimately leave the profession they love. In this session, learn how to implement a comprehensive financial well-being program that meets all employees, wherever the starting point, and takes them along a journey from surviving to thriving.

Sessions.Title: 8 Action Steps to Foster an Equitable Workplace
Sessions.Description: How does an educational workplace prioritize a culture of diversity and equity? When discrimination is not tolerated and employees are treated fairly, then they tend to be more productive and feel valued. In turn, these employees help foster positive learning environments for students. Learn practical steps to building a diverse and welcoming environment through bias awareness, fair practices, and diversity efforts.

Sessions.Title: Leading for Equity: Building a Culture of Equity in Richardson ISD
Sessions.Description: Learn about one district's journey to address equity, diversity, and inclusion and the timeline of events that led to the creation of an Equity Policy. District leadership will share the events and activities that continue to provide direction for supporting the district and its mission that "all means all."  Specific events, activities, and resources, including the adoption of an Equity Policy, will be shared.

Sessions.Title: Generating Equitable Youth Opportunities through Community Partnerships
Sessions.Description: In this panel discussion, experts will: outline the evidence base for OST learning; discuss programs' roles as capacity builders in broader educational ecosystems; and share tactical steps to build partnerships that innovate to meet student, district, and community needs. Panelists will also outline strategies for districts to leverage one-time federal investments beyond recovery to true transformation, building sustainable, student-centered collaborations for more equitable educational experiences.

Sessions.Title: Advocacy for Latino Learners and Leaders is Mission Critical
Sessions.Description: TALAS leadership will share the vision of the organization and discuss the priorities for advocacy/voice, as well as leadership development.

Sessions.Title: Addressing Equity in Secondary Mathematics
Sessions.Description: Join Rio Grande City CISD's leadership team as they share the "why" and "how" in their decision-making process to strategically partner with Agile Mind to eliminate barriers and drive success for all. With equity top of mind, Rio Grande City CISD has afforded students the opportunity to reach their academic and mindset potential through the implementation of a high-quality math/SEL curriculum and system-wide professional learning. The results speak for themselves.

Sessions.Title: Unpacking Implicit Biases
Sessions.Description: Through reflective discourse, participants will identify what implicit bias truly means, why the topic is relevant, and how to adjust teaching and leadership practices. Participants will leave the session with strategies to support how to react to culturally bias instances on campus how to teach, and lead in a sound, aware, and impactful manner.

Sessions.Title: Enrollment Strategies to Ensure Equity and Academic Success
Sessions.Description: Learn how one district uses strategic enrollment practices to combat systemic segregation and intentionally diversify schools. A 50/50 Socioeconomic Diversity Lottery creates a balanced school population in which 50 percent of the campus seats go to economically disadvantaged students and 50 percent go to non-economically disadvantaged students. Campuses are open to students across the district, and there are no attendance boundaries or academic entry requirements.

Sessions.Title: Equity as the Foundation: Strategic Planning to Achieve High Outcomes for Every Student
Sessions.Description: Austin ISD envisions becoming, "Austin's home for inclusive learning: high expectations for all children, high outcomes for every student," in their strategic plan. Listen to diverse perspectives on the challenging but essential work AISD undertook to align district and campus improvement planning to this vision of equitable outcomes for all. Lessons learned in AISD will offer helpful insight on how to build from a strong foundation of equity.

Sessions.Title: The Great Mismatch: District/School Culture and Disciplinary Practices
Sessions.Description: Disciplinary outcomes for the students of color from a historical perspective shows a direct correlation to administrator beliefs and current practices. Districts looking to increase academic outcomes for all students must consider how their beliefs and culture around discipline impacts those very outcomes. One critical area administrators and district leaders can close the achievement gaps is through changing cultures around discipline. Developing a more inclusive, restorative culture is key.

Sessions.Title: School Leadership and Changing Demographics: Leadership Competencies for Working with Demographically Diverse Students and Parents
Sessions.Description: This session will deliver an interactive format where participants will be given information about school outcomes due to changing student demographics. Participants will be asked to take a leadership inventory to determine if they have schools with changing demographics and identify the skillset necessary to lead schools undergoing demographic change. These leadership skills include data management, cultural competency, adapting to demographic change, and engagement with stakeholders of color.

Sessions.Title: JUST School Counseling: The Simplicity of School Counselor Advocacy
Sessions.Description: Cultivate fundamental skills to address educational and equitable needs of students while addressing required tasks of professional school counselors. Learn and apply this newly constructed but simple concept of "JUST School Counseling!"

Sessions.Title: 210 Additional Day School Calendar Redesign
Sessions.Description: The 210-additional-day school calendar redesign is a blueprint on reimagining a school calendar to accelerated learning experience. Participants will hear benefits to moving to a full redesign school calendar: additional planning time for teachers, brain breaks, special courses, increased recess and enrichment time for students. Participants will receive a timeline of events that should be considered as a district plans to implement a 210-additional-day school calendar.

Sessions.Title: More for Less: Staffing Models for Online Instruction
Sessions.Description: Do more for students while spending less money. Explore staffing options for online instructional models including remote and on-site learning at traditional and non-traditional campuses. View the costs and savings for different models. In peer groups, compare and contrast models and discuss strengths and challenges of implementation. As a culminating activity, self-assess your students' needs to determine which models best serve particular student groups on campus or district-wide.

Sessions.Title: CTO: Cybersecurity Audits
Sessions.Description: School districts have become the target of cybersecurity events resulting in loss of critical data. Recent legislative action has set an expectation for schools to work toward compliance using the Texas Cybersecurity Framework. Join a discussion about the cybersecurity audit process, how to use the information to inform budget and practice, and learn how these tools provide detection and prevention of a cybersecurity event.

Sessions.Title: Using Zero-Based Budgeting to Optimize Organizational Efficiency
Sessions.Description: Aligning resources to support the growing and diverse needs of a school system can be challenging. In this session, participants will learn the value of zero-based budgeting and how this model can be used to strategically align funding to support the district's strategic plan while creating organizational efficiencies. Additionally, this session will show how Aldine ISD has implemented zero-based budgeting and the benefits that have been achieved from it.

Sessions.Title: CTO: Protecting District Staff and Student Data
Sessions.Description: With the emergence of recent legislation, districts are required to provide assurance that student data is being protected. The Texas Student Privacy Alliance has created a common data privacy agreement to use with vendors across the state. Find out more about these free online tools, how to access the common agreement, keep track of your district agreements, and how your district can participate in the Alliance.

Sessions.Title: Better Healthcare: Don't Believe Me? Just Watch!
Sessions.Description: Raymondville ISD was the first district in Texas to offer an alternative to TRS-ActiveCare group health coverage. The district provided coverage at no cost to employees with a $0 deductible and $0 copay. Presenters will explain how the district offered better healthcare at a lower cost. These dynamic speakers will present the impact it had on the district and engage participants with stories from this experience.

Sessions.Title: Ditch the Deficit: Improve Quality by Bringing Foodservice In-House
Sessions.Description: Learn how Raymondville ISD increased revenues and cut costs while improving food quality and student satisfaction by bringing the foodservice program in-house.

Sessions.Title: Common Employer Mistakes in Workers Comp and How to Avoid Making Them
Sessions.Description: An employer who doesn't know what the law requires in regards to work comp reporting is vulnerable to fines and costly mistakes. Learn the state's requirements of political subdivisions while discussing the mistakes and misunderstandings commonly seen while handling claims.

Sessions.Title: Addressing ESSER Compliance and Financial Planning When Funds Run Out
Sessions.Description: Learn more about the tools that can empower leaders to communicate how ESSER funds are being used and the ways in which spending requirements are being met‚ while having a plan for how to proceed after these funds expire. See how Mansfield ISD is automating the process to review their ESSER budgets and planning for long-term budget sustainability. They will also show how they are tracking equity maintenance in regards to ESSER funding.

Sessions.Title: District-wide Impact: from the Campus to the Community
Sessions.Description: Capturing Kids' Hearts Leadership Strategist Ron Fox will sit down with two district leaders, Dr. Cissy Perez and Kimberley James, to explore how their teams are making a positive impact through a renewed focus on social and emotional learning, relationship-driven culture, and student connectedness. Both districts, in collaboration with Capturing Kids' Hearts, are implementing transformational processes that are yielding results from the campus to the community.

Sessions.Title: District Cybersecurity: Protecting Ports of Entry
Sessions.Description: To curb the trend of increasing cybercrime against school districts, leaders must understand how these attacks work. This presentation will examine the main "ports of entry" for successful cyberattacks, and explain how hackers plan and launch their attacks. This presentation also provide recommendations for preemptive defense and mitigation. Attendees will gain a better understanding of how hackers have been successful and what they can do to avoid becoming the next victim.

Sessions.Title: Amplifying Teacher Voice: Do You Hear What I Hear?
Sessions.Description: How does a superintendent hear directly from teachers and utilize their voice to systemically address problems of practice? Join Dr. Brian Woods as he shares a longstanding practice that is part of the district culture. Learn how the pandemic took this work to the next level. Walk away with ideas to recreate this process in your own district including sample documents. Q&A time will be provided.

Sessions.Title: What's your Superpower? Librarians as Agents of Transformation
Sessions.Description: Alignment of goals and objectives is crucial to growth, development, and transformation. School library programs have the potential to affect every student and every teacher on a campus. Discover how three school districts have strengthened library programs and librarians to support campus leadership initiatives through innovative, thoughtful partnerships with a variety of district departments, professional learning opportunities, and purposeful goal setting.

Sessions.Title: Going Beyond Compliance to Transform the Superintendent Evaluation into a Purposeful Strategic Process
Sessions.Description: In an effort to keep the board working at the governance level, the superintendent evaluation process is based on the district's culture, mission, vision, and strategic direction. It works as a tool to guide the board and superintendent in making the right decisions for the right reasons.

Sessions.Title: Governance Beyond the Team of 8: Developing School Cultures That Facilitate Success for All
Sessions.Description: Led by Laredo ISD trustees and the superintendent, this session will identify key components and strategies necessary to develop a culture of shared responsibility with which to drive positive student and organizational performance outcomes. Video and media samples will engage the audience in collaborative efforts to forge relationships enhancing the development of a Team of 8 in the boardroom as well throughout every school, department, and classroom in the district.

Sessions.Title: Three Amigas! Stopping the Malevolence of COVID Culture!
Sessions.Description: Come join the "Three Amigas" at the fiesta of the year! This fun, goofy, and insightful session will showcase how three amigas are stopping the malevolence of COVID culture with piñatas filled with surprises that will propel any organization to the place where everyone wants to be!

Sessions.Title: It Takes Teamwork: Developing Board Goals Between the Board and the Leadership Team
Sessions.Description: Medina Valley ISD develops board goals using a collaborative approach with the district leadership team. Meaningful and measurable goals are developed in order to lead to student, staff, and district success. These goals are then developed into the superintendent evaluation instrument, which is an objective, rather than subjective, document, focused on achieving the board goals. By goal-setting collaboratively, the board and the leadership team are continually improving the district.

Sessions.Title: Creating a Systemic Approach to Deeper Learning for All
Sessions.Description: How do districts cultivate students to be the creators of their future world? Engage and collaborate with other leaders as they explore the role of district and campus leadership in creating a culture and environment for deeper learning through the experiences of Leander ISD. Participants will leave with an understanding of district-level supports and collaboration needed for deeper learning.

Sessions.Title: Please Don't Make Me Read: A District's Journey in Building Value-Added Capacity
Sessions.Description: The session will include campus leadership along with the administrative assistants of their respective campuses and discuss the book study and professional development that was created to provide a new climate and culture in the school organization. This was the first time that the administrative assistants/secretaries had ever been involved in a book study and then required to create and present PD on changing culture and goal setting.

Sessions.Title: Teacher Incentive Allotment Planning for Small Districts
Sessions.Description: In this interactive presentation, participants will be able to post their questions, comments, and feedback about the path of a small school district pursuing Teacher Incentive Allotment. We will discuss the goals, the advantages, and disadvantages for participating in this statewide program. We'll share our experience in creating our incentive pay plan for highly effective teachers as well as what surprising outcomes we've had this year.

Sessions.Title: Navigating Community Conversations: Enlisting, Engaging and Empowering Conversations on Important Topics
Sessions.Description: Community input is invaluable, but engaging your community around a difficult topic can go south if not facilitated strategically. This session explores a method of engagement that frames a complex issue, seeks feedback, and mathematically unveils priorities to be assessed through the lens of implementation and training, effectiveness, and unintended consequences. District leaders share their success in using this method to address COVID-19, safety and security, and other complex issues.

Sessions.Title: Taking Strategy into Action
Sessions.Description: Listen and discuss with four superintendents who are working to create high-reliability districts while maintaining defined autonomy for mid-level managers in such a way that focus is narrowed to a few critical success factors that matriculate throughout organization utilizing a cascaded balanced scorecard.

Sessions.Title: Maximizing Growth by Leveraging Personalized Professional Development Plans
Sessions.Description: Kerrville ISd has worked for four years to create a Professional Learning Plan that was meaningful to staff and aligned with district goals, but teachers questioned the authenticity of the plan. This past year, they moved to a different format and campus and district leaders met in small groups to create individualized campus professional development plans. The process took five months to refine, but principals and teachers feel that the plan is developed specifically for the needs of their campus.

Sessions.Title: The Role of Education Foundations in District Long Range Planning
Sessions.Description: Education foundations are not just for wealthy, suburban communities; every school district can benefit from a supporting foundation. A superintendent and school attorney discuss strategies to incorporate education foundations into a school district's long term planning. Participants will learn how to create a supporting foundation and how foundation funds can be invested with fewer restrictions than school district funds in order to support student success in creative ways.

Sessions.Title: Becoming Exceptional: Leading Strategically through Campus Design Work
Sessions.Description: Believe that transformation is more about people and less about high-stakes testing? Committed to increasing student and staff engagement? Want to know what design work is and how it supports the strategic direction of a learning organization? Join several school leaders as they share their journey in using design work to build capacity, sustain change, and transform student learning.

Sessions.Title: Enhanced Improvement Planning by Engaging Multiple Measures of Data
Sessions.Description: Students and districts are more than a score. Using an assets-based approach, multiple measures tell a story and provide a starting point from which to launch targeted growth efforts that accelerate learning across the organization for every student. Learn how to meet students where they are, celebrate their gifts, and leverage their strengths to catapult their learning.

Sessions.Title: CTO: Considerations and Recommendations for Building a Teacher Incentive Allotment Cohort
Sessions.Description: Starting a TIA cohort can be daunting. In this session, review considerations and approaches to starting a TIA cohort. Topics discussed include student growth measures, teacher evaluation, calculating teacher designations, data triangulation, and district/campus culture.

Sessions.Title: Strategic Planning with an Equity Focus
Sessions.Description: Equity is a priority for many districts, but translating that priority into action is difficult. Strategic plans are critical, but they are a technical fix — words on paper intended to provide guidance. What makes those words powerful is the extent to which everyone believes them, understands them, and can see their role in implementing them. This session will outline how to meaningfully center equity within a strategic planning process.

Sessions.Title: Oh No You Didn't!
Sessions.Description: In this time of increased virtual learning and availability of online resources, digital citizenship instruction is more important than ever! Real stories of online behavior gone wrong, court cases, education law, and TEKS requirements elevate the importance of refocusing on digital citizenship in our schools. Join us for an interactive discussion of ideas, priorities, and solutions for digital citizenship for students and adults.

Sessions.Title: CTO: Funding Technology through ESSER, ECR, and TEACT
Sessions.Description: How has your school district taken advantage of the federal and state funding initiatives such as ESSER, ECR, and TEACT to purchase technology resources for virtual and blended learning? More important, how will your school district sustain funding when the federal funding is phased out? Participants will hear from and interact with a panel of technology and financial officers from three school districts how they addressed these questions.

Sessions.Title: Learning Here and Anywhere: Connecting at a Distance and Creating Meaning in Place
Sessions.Description: Education must evolve, creating new places for learning — material, digital, and in-between — to be resilient and impactful in an ever-changing world. Hybrid models of learning drawing from the best of in-person and online learning, and thoughtfully designed outdoor learning spaces can play a significant role. Expert educators, designers,and researchers illustrate how a strong sense of place, no matter the location or form, impacts student well-being and success.

Sessions.Title: Mind the Gap: Using Instructional Technology to Optimize Learning and Address Learning Loss
Sessions.Description: Before COVID, instructional technology use was fairly limited. However, now that teachers and students feel comfortable with these resources, districts must take advantage and leverage instructional technology to close gaps created by COVID and summer break. Although learning loss has recently been in the spotlight, it is nothing new. Teachers see learning loss every August. Join this session to discuss how to leverage instructional technology to "mind the gap."

Sessions.Title: Building Bridges Between School and Community with Entrepreneurial Education
Sessions.Description: Learn how an experiential entrepreneurial course inspires students to choose their own educational path while blending teacher-led instruction and business community expertise. The panel will highlight student success stories and allow participants to see how this program has bridged the gap between school and community.

Sessions.Title: TASA President's Dinner
What Happens When Corporations Support Schools?
Sessions.Description: This critical time in education has surrounding companies standing by and ready to make an impact. In partnership with Discovery Education, organizations like MLB, Toyota, and Chevron have been working hard to accelerate learning and create open-access resources around relevant topics, including STEM, SEL, career exploration, and more. Join us for an  overview of these engaging resources and collaborate on how organizations can do more to support schools and districts.

Sessions.Title: Places that Inspire: Early Childhood Environments for Student Success
Sessions.Description: This session will explore current research on early education and analyze how learning environments can support diverse learning modalities.  We will discuss how play-based learning, sensory learning, and social emotional learning can be positively impacted by introducing biophilic design features and connections to the outdoors.

Sessions.Title: The Customer Service Revolution in Schools and Its Impact on Trust and Culture
Sessions.Description: There's a quiet revolution of school leaders looking at how customer service and trust impacts their schools. Schools haven't traditionally called stakeholders — including parents, teachers/staff and taxpayers — their customers. But  expectations set by companies like Amazon are driving this trend. Hear from a panel of Texas school leaders who have instilled customer service-conscious cultures in their schools to support student success and identify problems before they become crises.

Sessions.Title: Creating a High Performance Culture through Customer Service
Sessions.Description: Culture matters, especially in an urban school district with more than 20,000 employees and 150,000 students. Culture will happen by default ... or it can be cultivated through intentional design. To promote a thriving, high-performing organization, educational leaders must develop (and model) those desired behaviors across all departments. Simply hoping for them is not an effective strategy! Dallas ISD has codified their culture based upon their CORE 4 tenets.

Sessions.Title: Using Analytics to Drive Strategic Decisions around Equity and Access
Sessions.Description: Learn how one Texas district drives its decision-making process to maximize student success. Ector County ISD has implemented a series of analytics to provide key insights and assessments, as well as challenges with remote learners and teacher incentive allotment. You'll also discover how ECISD has disaggregated its datasets to ensure equity and access for all students, and better align to district strategic goals.

Sessions.Title: The Future of School Administrative Spaces: Supporting the Next Generation Workforce through Efficient, Collaborative Design
Sessions.Description: Historically, schools have been defined by a culture of individualism. K-12 design efforts in recent years have mirrored commercial workplace trends by making a stance for collaborative areas, flexible seating, tech-savvy spaces, and cafeterias that mimic cafes. School design has been centric to teaching and learning, but supporting the education profession has been a low priority. The New CFISD Administration Building design portrays a reinvented paradigm for the school workplace.

Sessions.Title: Unmasking Financial Wellness: TRS, Social Security, and What You Can Do to Prepare
Sessions.Description: One of people's biggest fears is not having enough money for the future. That is understandable given 69% of Americans have less than $1,000 in savings and that pension systems appear complex. During the pandemic, many reflected on the type of financial future they desire, but struggled to identify actionable steps to improve their financial well-being. Let's unmask the issues and discuss the tools available to be financially well.

Sessions.Title: Connecting Human Resources to School Master Scheduling to Develop a Data-Driven Staffing Plan
Sessions.Description: With higher-than-normal teacher turnover, aligning staffing plans with emerging student-centered master scheduling needs has never been more important. Connecting hiring practices to school master scheduling facilitates equitable learning opportunities and improves the classroom experience for both students and teachers. Join our panel discussion for an in-depth look at making data-driven instructional and staffing decisions to hire smarter, save money, and retain your rock star teachers!

Sessions.Title: Using a Rich History to Chart a Successful Future
Sessions.Description: The community of Sherman has charted a course of continued prosperity and greater prominence for every student and every resident. That process started with the creation of comprehensive strategic plan that became a call to action and resulted in a successful bond and construction of the new Sherman High School. The methods for this journey blended an unremitting partnership with the city and unwavering commitment to community engagement and transparency.

Sessions.Title: Developing a Leadership Pathway
Sessions.Description: Using protocols to encourage collaboration, participants will take a brief deep dive into the significance of having a meaningful and aligned leadership development initiative that includes teachers, assistant principals, principals, and central office administrators. N2 Learning will highlight the Teacher Leadership Institute (TLI), the Assistant Principal Leadership Institute (APL), The Principals' Institute (PI), and the Executive Leadership Institute (ELI).

Sessions.Title: TASA Legislative Update
Sessions.Description: This session will focus on interim charges related to public education and legislative committee work. Regulatory changes coming from TEA, SBOE, SBEC, and other state agencies impacting public schools and a look at the political landscape heading into the March primary will also be covered.

Sessions.Title: Texas Leadership Center Board Meeting
TASA Leadership Luncheon
Sessions.Location: Austin Marriott Downtown - Waller Salon C

Sessions.Title: The Future of Testing and Accountability in Texas
Sessions.Description: In October 2021, a statewide team started meeting with 10,000 Texans in small and large group settings to educate stakeholders about the current accountability system and invite people to join Raise Your Hand Texas in the push for legislative change in the 88th legislative session. Become one of the 10,000 Texans raising their voices and find out how to engage local communities in this effort.

Sessions.Title: Can Superintendents Advocate? Yes!
Sessions.Description: Learn the basics of advocacy for school districts of all sizes from a former superintendent and trustee. Find out what can and can't be done, and how to include the school board and engage the community. Walk away with the confidence to start a conversation about advocacy to implement actions that range from simple to complex.

Sessions.Title: The Changing Landscape of School Health Insurance
Sessions.Description: The TASB Benefit Co-op will discuss recent legislation and how it impacts Texas school districts. Come learn about the TRS changes and other trends in benefits for school districts.

Sessions.Title: Overcome Compassion Fatigue, Lead and Serve from Abundance
Sessions.Description: When exhausted, spread thin, and giving from empty it can be incredibly challenging to show up fully for the people you serve (both professionally and personally). Learn why compassion plays a primary role in social-emotional learning, what's underneath the exhaustion and burnout, and what to do about it. Hear how shifting from a martyrdom to "model-dom" leadership model creates a ripple effect for district culture.

Sessions.Title: The Curriculum Management Audit: An Organizational Analysis Examining All Factors of Teaching and Learning
Sessions.Description: Looking for valuable feedback to improve learning for all students? Learn how curriculum management audit services can equip your leadership team with the tools necessary to objectively evaluate not only your curriculum, but all facets of the organization that impact student learning, and determine critical next steps in promoting student achievement. Hear from a district how curriculum management audit and related trainings can provide a structured approach to evaluating such areas as: curriculum, assessment, and program design; instructional delivery; equality and equity issues; and policy direction, planning for change, and goal prioritization.

Sessions.Title: TEA CTE Update: Participants, and Concentrators, and Completers, Oh My!
Sessions.Description: How is autocoding related to CCMR and funding? How can Summary and Supplemental Reports analyze whether the district is meeting the needs of all CTE Learners? Why are these two topics in the same session? The TEA CTE team will take provide a whirlwind tour of topics, including autocoding and the Comprehensive Local Needs Application (CLNA). Participants will leave the session empowered with additional knowledge to enhance student achievement, accountability, and funding.

Sessions.Title: General Overview of the STAAR Redesign
Sessions.Description: This session will provide updates about House Bill 3906 implementation, including a general overview of the STAAR redesign that will be implemented in the 2022-23 school year. The session will include how the redesign impacts all subjects, including resources available to support implementation of the STAAR assessment program.

Sessions.Title: Implementing a Coherent District Literacy Curriculum Framework
Sessions.Description: What does a literacy curriculum framework look like when incorporating Reading Academies, research-based instructional strategies, and high-quality literacy instructional materials?  Explore how districts have brought together these components to overhaul their literacy program into a comprehensive, coherent, literacy framework. This session will include district testimonials and opportunities for panel questions.

Sessions.Title: Aspiring Superintendents Academy
The Future of Educational Accountability Now
Sessions.Description: What should educational accountability look like going forward? Is the right accountability model in place? The answer is a clear no. Organizations and professions suffer great harm when they pick the wrong one and ask it to work beyond its design. This is exactly what happened in education and explains why the past 30 years have failed to produce the watershed moment most policymakers thought it would. Doubling down on what went before, no matter how well-intentioned, isn’t the answer. There's still a chance to create that watershed moment, but it requires an accountability system designed to get there. Come see what that system should look like and what schools are doing now to bring it about.

Sessions.Title: Relational Intelligence: Strategies to Reduce the Impact of Social Isolation
Sessions.Description: Join best-selling author Dr. Ruby Payne as she tackles the ongoing social effects of the pandemic on students. Future-ready students will need to have relational intelligence, and a key issue for schools will be how to mitigate the impact on brain development of social isolation. In this in-depth thought leader session, Dr. Payne will define relational intelligence, identify the impact of social isolation on adolescent brain development and relational intelligence, and highlight strategies to lessen the impact of social isolation as a result of COVID.
Sessions.Track Name(s): Student Support Services and Vulnerable Populations

Sessions.Title: The Innovator's Mindset
Sessions.Description: What is our vision for the future of learning, and how do we bring it to life? Sanée Bell says the following; “Students should have rich, relevant, and authentic experiences at school, across the board.” Are we recreating the same opportunities for our students that we had as students, or are we taking advantage of the opportunities our learners have today? Innovation in education is not about the "latest" technology but about creating new and better opportunities for our students. Why is it necessary to go beyond the idea of a "growth mindset" for our students, our staff, and our leadership, and why it is imperative to embrace the "Innovator's Mindset" at all levels of our organizations? In this session, George Couros will share compelling examples of the Innovator's Mindset that will make you laugh, cry, and think while reminding us to not only share the incredible stories from our schools but to create the stories we want to tell about our communities. You will walk away from this session not only feeling reaffirmed but challenged to move your learning to the next level!

Sessions.Title: Strengthening Teacher Agency with Impact Teams
Sessions.Description: When teams believe that collaboratively they have the expertise to develop assessment-capable, socially capable, and emotionally capable learners, they actually do! In this session, explore how Impact Teams leverage the sources of efficacy to amplify the most powerful influence over learning, collective teacher efficacy (CTE). Collective teacher efficacy (CTE) refers to a learning organization’s collective belief that through evidence-based, collective actions, they can positively advance student learning, including those students who are not contributing actively to their own learning or the learning of others. When teachers have agency, they have the capacity to act purposefully and constructively to direct their own professional growth and contribute to the growth of their colleagues.

Sessions.Title: Leading Restorative Practices
Sessions.Description: Restorative practices (RP) embrace a more connected way of being and responding to others in the community. RP is more than just a way of approaching discipline; it is a human centered approach to life and work. The most effective leaders have a restorative heart and mind set. They embrace their own humanity, and that of others, through reflection, growth, vulnerability and healing. Effective leaders ensure the same opportunities are provided to staff so that the workplace is not just efficient and effective, but also a place where conflict can be resolved and the work is approached with a collective focus on community. Come build a basic understanding of restorative practices, and leave with tangible resources to build systems, time, and space for restorative practices.

Sessions.Title: Clarity, Capacity, and Coherence: Key Practices for Developing Systems for Learning through Leadership
Sessions.Description: Prior to being a school administrator, Michael McDowell was a leadership and instructional coach for the New Tech Network, supporting educators in designing, implementing, and enhancing innovative schools across the country. His thought leader session will focus on developing educational systems that ensure more than one year’s growth in one year’s time for all learners in 21st century skills and academic content. McDowell will review the latest research in learning, leadership, and systems, and provide practical guidance for providing clarity of message, coherence of systems, and capacity development of employees to meet the growth demands articulated in the latest research.

Sessions.Title: An Encompassing Approach to School Safety: Prepare, Prevent, Protect
Sessions.Description: Michele Gay is the executive director of Safe and Sound Schools, which she co-founded with Alissa Parker after both lost children at Sandy Hook Elementary. Safe and Sound Schools is a national nonprofit school safety advocacy and resource center that provides research-based tools and support for crisis-prevention, response, and recovery. In this session, Michele will share Safe and Sound’s mission and model for a Collaborative Approach to School Safety. This presentation is aimed at a multi-disciplinary audience of educators, administrators, school resource officers, mental health professionals and school staff, as well as parent, student, and community representatives. Learn about tools, resources, and programs aimed at bringing all stakeholders in the school community together for a holistic and comprehensive approach to school safety.

Sessions.Title: Building Trust as a Foundation for Family-School Partnerships
Sessions.Description: Join family-school partnerships expert Dr. Karen Mapp for a thought leader session on building relational trust as a foundation for family-school partnerships this school year. Dr. Mapp is the leading national expert in fostering positive partnerships between schools and families. Research shows that leveraging family-school and community partnerships improves student outcomes across key metrics. She will help district leaders break down the key components of building strong relationships with families as well as community partners through an asset-based lens in order to improve student outcomes.

Sessions.Title: Nobody Does Leadership Like H-E-B: A Conversation with H-E-B President Craig Boyan and TASA’s Kevin Brown
Sessions.Description: In this thought leader session, H-E-B's Craig Boyan and TASA's Kevin Brown will talk about the way H-E-B has supported the company’s team members and customized their approach for each community they serve. The pair will also discuss the toll the pandemic has taken on leaders in business and education, and the lessons they’ve learned while leading through historically challenging times.

Sessions.Title: Building Language Skills to Create a Positive Early Learning Environment
Sessions.Description: Dr. Zucker will explore evidence-based practices that help accelerate young children’s language, literacy, and social-emotional development. Participants will learn how to utilize purposeful serve-and-return conversation to help children acquire the social-emotional, oral language, and vocabulary skills they need to thrive in a positive classroom environment, implement best practices that enhance language skills, and understand types of questions that are developmentally appropriate for promoting vocabulary at school and home.
